'CÃ©cile Fatiman' (fl. 1791), was a Haitian vodou priestess, a mambo (Voodoo).
She is famous for her participation in the vodou ceremony at Bois CaÃ¯man, which
is considered to be one of the starting points of the Haitian Revolution.

CÃ©cile Fatiman was the daughter of an African slave woman and a white Corsican
man. She and her mother were sold as slaves at Saint Domingue, while her two
brothers disappeared in the slave trade. [http://books.google.se/books?id=8-
11XSbCPRH8C&pg=PA47&dq=C%C3%A9cile+Fatiman&hl=sv&ei=f6fWTrPjOcj04QT886nEAQ&sa=X-
&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=C%C3%A9cile%20Fa-
timan&f=false Haiti, History, and the Gods by Joan Dayan] She is described
as having long silky hair and green eyes. [http://books.google.se/books?id=-
811XSbCPRH8C&pg=PA47&dq=C%C3%A9cile+Fatiman&hl=sv&ei=f6fWTrPjOcj04QT886nEAQ&sa=-
X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=C%C3%A9cile%20F-
atiman&f=false Haiti, History, and the Gods by Joan Dayan]

In August 1791, Fatiman presided over a ceremony at the Bois CaÃ¯man in the role
of mambo together with priest Dutty Boukman. Boukman prophesied that the slaves
Jean FranÃ§ois, Biassou, and Jeannot would be leaders of a resistance movement
and revolt that would free the slaves of Saint-Domingue. An animal was
sacrificed, an oath was taken, and Boukman and the priestess exhorted the
listeners to take revenge against their French oppressors and "[c]ast aside the
image of the God of the oppressors." Charles Arthur and Michael Dash (eds.)
LibÃ¨te: A Haiti Anthology (Princeton, NJ: Markus Wiener Publishers, 1999),
36. According to the Encyclopedia of African Religion, "Blood from the
animal, and some say from humans as well, was given in a drink to the attendees
to seal their fates in loyalty to the cause of liberation of Sainte-
Domingue." Molefi Kete Asante and Ama Mazama. Encyclopedia of African
religion, Volume 1 Sage Publications, p. 131. During the ceremony, CÃ©cile
Fatiman acted as if she were possessed by the goddess Erzulie. [http://book-
s.google.se/books?id=wFrAOqfhuGYC&pg=PA390&dq=Cecile+Fatiman&hl=sv&ei=9bPWTsvUO-
8jE4gTY2KyPAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBTgK#v=onepag-
e&q&f=false Africa and the Americas: culture, politics, and history, by Richard
M. Juang] She was also said to have cut the throat of a pig and offered
its blood to the spectators. [http://books.google.se/books?id=wFrAOqfhuGYC&-
pg=PA390&dq=Cecile+Fatiman&hl=sv&ei=9bPWTsvUO8jE4gTY2KyPAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&-
ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q&f=false Africa and the
Americas: culture, politics, and history, by Richard M. Juang] A week
later, 1800 plantations had been destroyed and 1000 slaveholders
killed. Sylviane Anna Diouf, Servants of Allah p. 152 John Mason.
[http://www.scribd.com/doc/6210488/African-Religous-In-The-Caribbean-Continuity-
Change-by-John-Mason African Religions in The Caribbean: Continuity and
Change]

Fatiman was married to Louis Michel Pierrot, a general in the Haitian
revolutionary army and later president. [http://books.google.se/books?id=81-
1XSbCPRH8C&pg=PA47&dq=C%C3%A9cile+Fatiman&hl=sv&ei=f6fWTrPjOcj04QT886nEAQ&sa=X&-
oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=C%C3%A9cile%20Fat-
iman&f=false Haiti, History, and the Gods by Joan Dayan] She is reported
to have lived to the age of 112. [http://books.google.se/books?id=811XSbCPR-
H8C&pg=PA47&dq=C%C3%A9cile+Fatiman&hl=sv&ei=f6fWTrPjOcj04QT886nEAQ&sa=X&oi=book-
